learning_outcomes.description: Comprehend the distinctions and roles of functional foods and nutraceuticals as options to support health.
Comprehend and summarise the active ingredients in functional foods and nutraceuticals, emphasising their health benefits.
Review legislation governing functional foods and nutraceuticals.
Critically analyse and synthesize evidence on functional foods and nutraceuticals, independently/collaboratively relating findings to health claim.
Interact & engage with others to effectively communicate scientific information visually.

assessments.weighting: <dd>30% Each quiz contributes 15% towards the 30% weighting.  </dd>
assessments.task_description:
Quiz 1 will be based on the Weeks 1 and 2 lecture content.

Quiz 2 will be based on the Weeks 5 and 6 lecture content.

The quizzes will be conducted in-class, online via Blackboard during lecture hours. You will have 20 minutes to complete the quiz worth 15 marks in a single session, and only one attempt will be permitted. The quiz will include various questions: short answer, essay, fill-in-the-blank, and true-or-false.

Each quiz contributes 15% to your overall grade.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Students are responsible for ensuring a stable internet connection while undertaking an online test/quiz. The quiz is taken on the UQ campus, with a secure connection.

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the online test/quiz: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Advise the Course Coordinator during the session. AskUs can assist if required: support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
Week 7 Tue - Week 10 Tue

Presentations will be delivered during scheduled tutorial sessions.
assessments.task_description:
Overview: This is a group assessment completed in groups of four self-selected students, managed via Blackboard. Instructions on how to create or join a group in Blackboard will be provided in Week 1. Groups will be formed in Week 1–2. Students who do not have a group may use the Blackboard group tool (and tutorial class time) to connect with others, and teaching staff can assist in matching students where possible. Students must be in a group by the end of Tutorial Session 2; students who have not joined a group by this date will be allocated to a group.

Each group will be allocated one functional component (e.g., fibre, calcium, polyphenols). Across Tutorial Sessions 2–6, groups will research the assigned component and identify four different market products that contain it (one product per student).

Tutorial time will support planning and coordination; however, additional meetings outside scheduled classes are expected. The instructor will be available during tutorials to answer questions.

Submission and timing

  • Poster submission: Only one group member needs to submit the poster on behalf of the group via the relevant Turnitin link on Blackboard by 02/04/2026, 16:00
  • Presentations: Delivered during tutorial sessions in Weeks 7–10. The presentation timetable will be availble on Blackboard in Week 4.


Details of the Poster Presentation assessment are outlined below:

Part A: Functional component overview

Each group will investigate the assigned functional component and include the following on the poster:

1)    What the functional component is (definition);

2)    Why it is considered functional in foods; and

3)    Key health benefit(s) and a brief, clear health mechanism (a simple diagram is encouraged).

Part B: Product (one product per student)

Each group member must identify one different market product that contains the assigned functional component and provide a product summary on the poster that includes:

1)    Product name and product category;

2)    Serving size (as stated on pack);

3)    Functional component amount per serve (if stated), OR a numeric proxy if not stated (e.g., % cocoa, % wholegrain, % fruit/berry, quantified ingredient %);

4)    A brief explanation of why the ingredient is functional and the health mechanism (short and specific);

5)    A justification for why the product is a strong vehicle for health benefit delivery (e.g., formulation/food matrix, portion realism, consumer use context); and

6)     One limitation (e.g., sugar/sodium load, low dose, processing, allergens, cost).

Presentation verification requirement: During your pitch, each student must briefly show the product label (pack or label image) and point to where the functional component is evidenced on-pack (Nutrition Information Panel, ingredients list, or a quantified claim). This is to ensure product-specific analysis and individual ownership.

Part C: Product comparison and final recommendation

The group should compare the four products using a decision matrix and select the best product. This section must include:

1)    A decision matrix comparing all four products using the criteria below; and

2)    The group’s final choice: best product + 2–3 lines justification explaining why it provides the strongest potential health benefit.

Decision matrix criteria (all groups must use these):

  1. Strength of functional component dose/indicator (label-based)
  2. Mechanism alignment (does the product plausibly deliver the effect?)
  3. Portion realism (is the serving size realistic for consumers?)
  4. Practicality (availability, cost, allergens/diet suitability)
  5. Limitations (e.g., sugar/sodium/processing concerns)

 

Poster format and submission requirements

Submission: Submit a two-page PDF as a single file via Blackboard/Turnitin. Only one group member needs to upload the file on behalf of the group.

  • Page 1: A1 poster (all main content must be on this page)
  • Page 2: References only (no additional figures, tables, or content)


Poster presentation (Tutorial) - Weeks 7-10

Each group will deliver a poster presentation during the tutorial session, based on the poster they have submitted.

Format: One group pitch based on the poster

Duration: 8 minutes total (timed)

Recommended structure of presentation:

  • Group introduction
  • Each student presents their own product section
  • Group decision matrix + best product recommendation + key takeaway

 

Peer Assessment

Each group member will evaluate the contribution of the other members to the poster and preparation for the presentation using the course peer assessment tool on Blackboard.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately. Please see the assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

  • This learning activity is delivered through a structured lecture series that introduces functional foods and nutraceuticals and applies key concepts across major food categories.
  • Lectures cover: Introduction to Functional Foods & Nutraceuticals; Functional Components in Milk (I–II); Regulatory Environment and Health Claims; Functional Components in Cereals (I–II); Functional Components in Fruits & Vegetables (I–II); Functional Components in Tea, Coffee & Cocoa, Herbs and Spices, Seafoods & Meat, and Microalgae.
  • Each lecture focuses on the bioactive components within the food group and how these relate to proposed health effects and the evidence base underpinning claims.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture Series This learning activity is delivered through a structured lecture series that introduces functional foods and nutraceuticals and applies key concepts across major food categories. Lectures cover: Introduction to Functional Foods & Nutraceuticals; Functional Components in Milk (I–II); Regulatory Environment and Health Claims; Functional Components in Cereals (I–II); Functional Components in Fruits & Vegetables (I–II); Functional Components in Tea, Coffee & Cocoa, Herbs and Spices, Seafoods & Meat, and Microalgae. Each lecture focuses on the bioactive components within the food group and how these relate to proposed health effects and the evidence base underpinning claims.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 10(02 Mar - 10 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial Series

Tutorials support the lecture series through guided, evidence-based application and assessment preparation. Tutorials are interactive sessions where students apply lecture concepts through discussion and structured activities. Students work in self-selected groups to explore an assigned functional component and analyse market products that contain it. Tutorials also include assessable group presentations (from Week 7), where each student explains their allocated product and demonstrates product-specific analysis using on-pack label information. Tutorial time is used for group planning, coordination, and applying evidence-based reasoning to product claims, with staff available to answer questions and provide feedback.


Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05
